question: Ic (willan) #### mid flode folc acwellan ond cynna gehwilc cwicra wihta — I intend to kill with a flood the people and every kind of living creature
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the first person singular form 'wille' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwyder (willan) #### ðu ga? — Where do you intend to go?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the second person singular form 'wilt' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Se biscop sceal þe (willan) #### onfon Godes mildheortnesse þrafian þa mæssepreostas mid lufe ond mid laþe þæt hie healdan Godes æwe on riht — The bishop that wants to obtain God's mercy, must compel the priests with love and with fear to correctly preserve God’s law
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the third person singular form 'wile' as the subject is 'se biscop'

question: Þry dagas to lafe sindon þæt hie þe (willan) #### acwellan — Three days remain before the day comes on which they intend to kill you
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the plural form 'willaþ' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Forðy ic (willan) #### ðætte hie ealneg æt ðære stowe wæren — Therefore I wanted them always to be there at that place
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past first person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Ic geanbidode swiðe wel oð ic wisse hwæt ðu (willan) #### and hu ðu hit understandan woldest — I waited very willingly until I knew what you wanted and how you would understand it
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past second person singular form 'woldest' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: He cwæð ðæt he (willan) #### þæm wife gemyltsian — He said that he wanted to pardon the woman
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past third person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Loð þa eode to his twam aðumum þe (willan) #### wifian on his twam dohtrum — Lot then went to his two sons in law, who intended to marry his two daughters
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past plural form 'woldon' as the subject is 'his twam aðumum'

question: Hwæt (willan) #### ic ðissum wiðersacan geandwyrdan? — What answer will I give to this denial?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the first person singular form 'wille' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Cwædon him to: Gif þu ne (willan) #### us geðafian in swa æðelicum þinge þe we biddað ne meaht þu in usse mægðe ne ussum gemanan wunian — They said to him: 'If you will not consent to us in so noble a matter, as we ask, you may not dwell in our country nor in our society'
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the second person singular form 'wilt' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Elpendes hyd (willan) #### drincan wætan, gelice spynge deð — An elephant’s hide will absorb liquid, like a sponge does
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the third person singular form 'wile' as the subject is 'Elpendes hyd'

question: Þonne þy ilcan dæge þe hie hine to þæm ade beran (willan) #### todælað hie his feoh — Then on the same day when they intend to bear him to the pyre, they divide his wealth
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the plural form 'willaþ' as the subject is 'hie'

question: He nyste hwæt ic (willan) #### — He didn't know what I wanted
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past first person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwi (willan) #### þu beswican þæt mære wif Melantian mid forligre? — Why would you entice that excellent woman Melantian with fornication?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past second person singular form 'woldest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Þa Darius geseah þæt he ouerwunnen beon wolde, þa (willan) #### he hiene selfne on ðæm gefeohte forspillan — When Darius saw that he would be overrun, then he wanted to kill himself on the battlefield
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past third person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Ond wið þæm þa ðe in oðre wisan don (willan) #### he wæs mid welme micelre ellenwodnisse onbærned — And against those who wanted to do otherwise he was inspired with great fervor and zeal
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past plural form 'woldon' as the subject is 'þæm'
